subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and today I'd like to talk about money.
Some people would be inclined to say that money is not a very spiritual topic. I beg to differ.
I think that money is right at the root of our spirituality. In fact,
I mean that literally because when we talk about the chakra system,
the great Indian system of the subtle spiritual
physiology of the body, the root chakra [is] at the base of the spine,
sometimes symbolized by the coiled serpent of Kundalini and sometimes symbolized by a dragon, a dragon
guarding its gold inside of its cave. The root chakra is
where we have the instinct to hoard, the instinct to
accumulate wealth for ourselves. And it's interesting, this is the very first
chakra. So when Sigmund Freud, for example, developed his theory of the unconscious and said that it
mostly contains the libido, or sexual
energies, and our aggressive desires, things that are considered somewhat taboo subjects in a civilized
Victorian society in which Freud grew up-- well,
he wasn't really Victorian English-- but in the 19th century and early 20th century,
there were things that were simply not
acceptable to talk about in polite company. But, money is even deeper than sex and aggression.
We live in a culture that is dominated by
materialism and the quest for money. I
hardly know anybody who doesn't think about money
much of the time, maybe all of the time. So much of our self-esteem
is tied up in how much we’re worth, how much we have. Not only that, but money represents
personal freedom, our ability to
have what we want to have and our sense of things that we will never have and
our ability to go where we want to go when we want to do it. It's all related to money.
I'd like to add that I think our culture,
globally, is very much out of balance when it comes to money. For example, in wealthy countries
there's an epidemic of obesity, whereas in poor countries, there's an epidemic of
malnutrition and even death by starvation.
In a world where there's plenty of food for everybody, that seems to be a
spiritual crime.
Now, most of you probably don't know that money is actually a very big interest of mine. In fact,
financial forecasting has been one of my top
interests for the last
20 years, nearly, since my dear friend and colleague Dean Brown
began to share with me his methods of financial forecasting.
I've been pursuing this area intensely. In fact, I have a website and you can link to it right now
in the upper right hand corner of your screen. It's called alphainterface.com. And what I do
there is, I follow the financial information
regarding systems for forecasting the future because I have a big interest in precognition and, in particular,
precognition of the financial markets. It's very important to me to be
knowledgeable about the non-psychic means for forecasting the financial markets.
I can tell you that market timing is one of the most difficult things anybody can do. But, there are some very interesting
approaches available using technical analysis and
artificial intelligence and so on. I try to, in a small way, keep up with the latest research
findings on that website. For me, money is like the blood of
the social body that we live in. If you think of the human body as energized and
made alive by blood, well, money moves through society much the same way.
And I'm interested in following
financial trends in order to understand, at a spiritual level, what things are important to people.
What industries are gaining?
What industries are losing? That says a lot to me about the global
consciousness of the planet. I
should say one other thing about money. What does it mean to you? And, what does it mean to me?
Why do I, for example,
spend a lot of my time and
also my resources in putting these videos out, making them available
to you at no cost? Although, I'm certainly happy to
receive donations from any of you who care to log on to our foundation
newthinkingallowed.org. You'll see you can
purchase books there and some artwork or donate directly to our production. It helps,
but I can tell you this, it only offsets - and including the
advertising that we're now doing - a tiny amount of our expenses. But, I do it because for me
it's a form of karma yoga. It's a form of being in service to humanity. And you know what, I've got enough money
anyway. But let's look at this question of, “how much is enough?”
Some people would say that they never have enough,
they never can have enough, there's always more. You could be a
multi-millionaire, you could be a
multi-billionaire and still want more. I think
there are some people who would like to be the richest person in the world. I imagine even if you were the
richest person on this planet you might still think you didn't have enough. Now, in the Jewish tradition
there's a text called “Pirkei Avot,” the “Sayings of Our Fathers.”
Probably the most popular of these sayings goes something like this, “Who is rich?” And
the answer is, “He who is content with what he has.” Now,
I don't quite buy that. I think it's good to have goals. I think it's good to have desires.
I think it's good to want to improve your situation in many ways. But, perhaps
financially isn't the most important, although perhaps it
is. There are some people who are desperate, even in this wealthy country of
ours. Not enough people can afford to put food and
medicine on their table together at the same time.
It's often one gets sacrificed in the name of the other. We live in a culture where
the poor people seem to blame the rich people for all the problems in the world. The rich people
blame the poor people for all the problems in the world.
Money is really, I would say, at the root of
almost all problems that we face.
Some people are far, far too attached to what they have and hoarding it and
hoping to increase it way beyond their reasonable needs. Other people don't have enough for the basic
necessities of life.
If we want a world that works for everybody,
this is a problem that needs to be addressed. And I don't think
it's being addressed, frankly. If anything, the situation seems to be getting worse, not better.
So let me leave you with this thought.
What does money mean to you? How much of your mental and emotional
energy is
focused on the thought that you don't have enough, that you're not happy with what you have in
life? How much of that is healthy and how much of it isn't? I'll leave you with those thoughts.
Thank you for being with me.
